fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1690].
  {panel}

h4. Problem

JIRA Portfolio allows very fine-grained configuration and setup of plans, making sure that customers can adapt the tool to their complex planning requirements. However, this complexity leaves room for errors and often times it is difficult to figure out what may have been misconfigured.

As an example, there are a number of possible causes why a certain issue or issues do not show up in the plan. [This Atlassian Answers thread|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/38390402/issues-not-showing-up-in-portfolio-live-plans] lists a number of them.
h4. Suggestion

Following the success of the [JIRA Admin Helper|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver071/jira-admin-helper-802593078.html], it would be very helpful to have a {{JIRA Portfolio Helper}} that could be used to determine the answers for the questions like (but not limited to):
 * Why does _X issue_ not show up in my Portfolio plan?
 * Why is my release _red_? (Suggestions on possible solutions)
 * What else would fit in this release with fixed release date?
 * Why does my capacity report show bottleneck?
 * What changes I need to make to my existing projects _X_ and _Y_ in order to see them on the same plan? (suggest on missing releases/fix versions, large delta between teams' velocity, incompatible capacity measures)

 

Through this feature, customers could self-help and adjust issue sources accordingly, determine the logic behind specific scheduling "decisions" by the algorithm.
fields.summary: JIRA Portfolio Helper
Draft plan edits should be scoped to the individual until committed
As a project manager, I want to be able to mark the skills needs for an issue so that the right individual can be assigned

fields.description:
h2. Update 28/Apr/2020
{panel:title=28/Apr/2020| borderStyle=dashed| borderColor=#3C78B5| titleBGColor=#3C78B5| bgColor=#E7F4FA}
After careful analysis and assessing potential solutions for this bug, and although we appreciate that having to remove each Portfolio add-on separately can be cumbersome, we have decided to close this bug as "Won't Fix".

Since the universal plugin manager does not allow to specify which plugins belong together, the way Portfolio is packaged would have to be reengineered. We believe that the time and effort required to do it would be better invested in other priorities.
{panel}
 
----
h3. Issue summary

Currently when JIRA Portfolio is installed, this actually installs 3 add-ons:
 * Portfolio for JIRA
 * Portfolio Live Plans
 * Portfolio Team Management

If a customer wants to uninstall/disable JIRA Portfolio, they'd have to actually go through each add-on to uninstall. If only one of the items are uninstalled, but not others, it can result in odd behaviours in the system.

In one case, the logs were spammed with:
{code:java}
2016-10-25 12:59:34,607 http-nio-8080-exec-88 WARN admin 779x1513687x3 1tk8azs 10.34.155.42,10.33.48.156 /secure/AjaxIssueAction!default.jspa [c.a.r.j.p.w.children.condition.ChildIssuesPanelVisibilityCondition] Exception when evaluating if child issues panel should be displayed.
{code}
 * There were 10s of thousands of these messages:
{code:java}
grep -c 'c.a.r.j.p.w.children.condition.ChildIssuesPanelVisibilityCondition' atlassian-jira.log*
atlassian-jira.log:19858
atlassian-jira.log.1:24540
{code}

h4. Expectation

There should be some sort of indication to inform the admin of plugin dependencies, or the removing one add-on should also remove the others.
fields.summary: Uninstalling Portfolio should uninstall all dependencies that were Installed with the Bundle
Components Available from JIRA and Porfolio
Sum Custom Field Values

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1684].

h3. Problem
When excluding issues from a plan in Portfolio, you are not able to exclude just a single issue if the ticket is in a hierarchy like Epic, Task, Sub-task.

h3. Suggestion
Allow to exclude individual issues from Portfolio Plans

h3. Workaround
None
fields.summary: Let Child/Parent issues be excluded individually from a plan

fields.description:
h3. Reproduce
* Create a story with an estimated subtask
* Create a team with some persons
* Assign the subtask to a person
* Calculate
* Open the schedule and group by persons - the story/subtask is assigned to a wrong person

h3. Workaround
Assign the subtask correctly in JIRA. This still works as long as the JIRA assignee is in the same team that is assigned to the story of the subtask. Note that this only works for actual JIRA issues and JIRA users.
fields.summary: Portfolio resource assignments are ignored for sub-tasks

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When accessing any Portfolio pages in JIRA with Websudo triggered the menu bar of JIRA disappears. 
  
h3. Environment

Happening with the following setup:
 * JIRA 6.4.12 and JIRA Portfolio 2.1.2
 * JIRA 7.2.2 and JIRA Portfolio 2.1.2

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Trigger any Admin operation such as Viewing Incoming Mail server - this will ask the user to login as Admin user. Notice there will be a banner on top of the page informing the user that the user has temporary Admin access.
 # Access any Portfolio page.

h3. Expected Results

JIRA menu bar will be still visible with the Websudo banner is showing.
  
h3. Actual Results

JIRA 6.4.12:
 !jpo_banner_6412.png|thumbnail! 
 JIRA 7.2.2:
 !jpo_banner_722.png|thumbnail!
h3. Notes
 * The banner can be dismissed when the user drops the temporary Admin access.
 * This behaviour only affects users with Admin access. 

h3. Workaround

No workaround found for this problem yet.
fields.summary: JIRA Menu bar is missing when accessing Portfolio pages with Websudo triggered
Parent Link and Team fields should be editable for users without Portfolio edit permission

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1679].
  {panel}

*Story:* As a Program Manager I want to add JQL quick filters to the top of my Portfolio plan, so that I can use specific business/team logic relevant to the teams & initiatives based on the exact queries I need. 

*Details:*
* Create an admin page like the Quick Filter page under the Configuration of an Agile Board. 
* Allow for any JQL statement (exactly as the Agile Boards do) to be saved/used.
* Toggle button interface exactly as set up on Agile Boards (and competing product BigPicture), to single click and have the portfolio filter to that specific subset of data

*Problem this is solving* 
* Each company is different, and the standard portfolio filtering fields can't cover all use cases/combinations that are needed for managing the different environments & industries that could benefit from this tool
* It opens the door to filtering by custom fields, which many customers rely heavily on and use throughout Jira and Agile Boards. 
* Reduces requests to the Portfolio team for more drop down lists in addition to the existing 8 that are available. If users can create their own filters, it should reduce the additional filtering functionality that the team would have to build.
fields.summary: Quick Filter Functionality in Jira Portfolio

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1678].
  {panel}

*Story:* As a C-Level leader, I want a flexible, intuitive chart view at the highest level cross-team initiatives, so that I can selectively expand/collapse any initiative to understand the work, teams, epics and blockers within it.

*Details:*
* Full screen view showing a bar chart with the name of the top level initiative and agile timeline spanning number of sprints (based on anticipated velocity, exactly as Portfolio currently calculates), with possible dates overlaid if relevant. 
* Ability to selectively click into each initiative to dive into the component Epics, then stories, subtasks, etc... (entire hierarchy)
* Clear view of blocking/blocked issues, with indicators (lines?) to what is blocking/blocked by it. 
* Clear coloring of issues either by status, or ideally by custom configuration (along the lines of card color logic available on Agile Boards)

*Problem this is solving* 
* Current view makes you choose the overall level (Story Level, Epic Level, etc...), which in larger engineering companies (30+ teams working on large cross-team initiatives) quickly makes it unusable
* Alternate view within current Portfolio is by Project, which doesn't cover the cross-team dependencies that emerge in larger setups or when building a micro-services environment (teams for Database/API/etc... that will play smaller roles in many different projects)
* Current blocking implementation is harder to see (slighter shaded blue) and doesn't indicate what it is actually blocking until you click on it. When you have dozens of relationships like this, that become impractical quickly to visualize where your problems are in the pipeline. 
* The biggest alternate portfolio products on the market show views like this, but can't handle the Agile/iterative/points component of the equation. Jira Portfolio DOES handle that piece, and building an agile version of this view becomes a clear delineator in the market. 

*Note:* For the sake of my examples, calling the highest-level issue type _Initiative_, please substitute as needed.
fields.summary: Create Agile Gantt-Like Chart for Portfolio
Add 'Import Themes' from other Portfolio's
reporting

fields.description:
*Current Behaviour: *
When opening up labels picker in Portfolio scope table, attempting to type in the field and retrieve a suggestion for the label name will result in an error.

A suggestion for a currently existing label name is shown, otherwise a suggestion to create a new label is shown.

*Workarounds:*
None
fields.summary: Error when attempting to get suggestion for Labels field in Portfolio

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1674].
  {panel}

h3. Summary  
Currently, Portfolio allows custom fields that are not available for issues to be displayed in the Scope. When updating and committing the value of the custom field, the issue in JIRA gets updated with the value as well. The problem is that the custom field is not being used for the given issue/project. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce 
# Create a custom field such as a number field (Make sure it is not available on create, edit and view screens for your given project, but it is available for all projects (Project context: Global (all issues))
# Add the custom field to your plan by going to Configure > Custom Fields > Add Custom Field
# Update the custom field with a value and commit your changes
# The issue in JIRA is now updated with a value for the custom field (visible in change history), even though the custom field is not available on view and update screen for issue. 


h3. Expected Results  
Portfolio would not even show custom fields that are not associated with the project/filter

h3. Actual Results 
Portfolio displays custom fields that are not associated with the given project/filter

h3.Workaround 
No workaround
fields.summary: Portfolio allows custom fields that are not available for issues
Unlock the Team field

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1671].
{panel}
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, there is an upper limit of 50 teams, 100 Projects and 5000 open issues per plan due to performance restriction. 

!image-2016-10-14-14-16-33-277.png!

 
h3. Suggested Solution

We want to make this more scalable and allowing more project and issues per plan to support larger clients.
h3. Workaround

None.

 
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 7 January 2018}
Hi All,

Thank you for commenting on this issue with your feedback. I’d like to give you a quick update on this feature improvement. We’re continuously investigating solutions to improve performance, but loading & viewing a very large amount of issues at once is complex. 

The issue & project limits most likely won't be extended in the next few months. The Reason is that we chose to invest most of our effort in simplifying the UI with a brand new design, details can be found [here|https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Portfolio-for-Jira-articles/Introducing-a-new-planning-experience-in-Portfolio-for-Jira/ba-p/944996]. 

We know that this is a major issue for some of you and longer term ( 12-18 months ) we will  increase our efforts to extend these limits in a way that won’t lower performance.

In the meantime, I would advise customers to split their work streams into different plans. You could use the [Programs feature|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiraportfolioserver/programs-931037964.html] to get an aggregated view of multiple plans, for basic reporting functionality.  

Roi Fine | Product Manager 
{panel}
fields.summary: Increase the project, issue, and team limits in Plan
Zoom the timeline without filtering the scope

fields.description: We are working on a fix and will release it shortly.
fields.summary: New teams cannot be committed in MySql

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
1) Create child issue of an Epic in Portfolio
2) Commit child issue to JIRA
3) Attempt to view Epic Link of child issue in JIRA

Outcome:
- Epic link is not set, but if you add a Parent link custom field to the issue, it can be seen there instead.
- It includes the warning _to set an epic as the parent, use the epic link instead_

Expected:
- Epic link is set on the issue
- Parent link is empty
fields.summary: Parent-Link is set instead of Epic-Link when creating issues with parent epics
Is the Portfolio "Team" field available in Jira Boards?
Timeline View - add 'Group by Epic' as an option in Story View
If dependency is at parent level this should be displayed on children issues and vice versa

fields.description:
*Symptoms*
The _Sprints_ option is disabled in the schedule configuration fly-out in plans using skills even when all teams are already on the same schedule

*Expectation*
The _Sprints_ option is available when all teams are on the same schedule, i.e., have the same planning mode, sprint length (if appropriate) and custom sprints (if connected to board issue sources)

*Actual behaviour*
The _Sprints_ option is greyed out when there is a plan that has skills configured and the sprints of the respective teams show different bottlenecks / free capacities in the _Capacity_ view

*Work-around*
Filter your backlog to one particular team or just group the schedule by _Teams _or _Members_ if you wish to see Sprint information

We are already working on a fix.
fields.summary: Sprint option for schedule view is potentially disabled in plans using skills

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1663].
  {panel}

As per all of the comments here: [https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/39986944/answers/40347822/comments/43110013]

The key concerns for us with the current implementation are:
 * It's not possible to use ScriptRunner's JQL functions (or indeed functions from a variety of add ons) to find children of initiatives that meet certain criteria. With a normal link, or even epic link, it is possible to run JQL to find all linked issues where the parent issue meets certain criteria - for enterprise this is absolutely critical.
 * It's not possible to update the field via scripts, it's possible to do this for epic links
 * It's not possible to use add ons like Structure to build hierarchies as this isn't a real link type
 * It's not possible to use this field for any kind of reporting outside of JIRA as it doesn't extract the issue key

This basically means the current implementation of the field/JQL is only useful if you want to find the epics linked to known parent initiatives, which only works if you have a small set of initiatives to work with - we have thousands, and cannot currently create a background link to use for searching when a "parent link" is created because we can't access the field value via scripts.

Please feel free to contact me if you would like more information about our use cases.
fields.summary: Parent link should behave in the same way as epic link (i.e. forming a link in the background)
Timeline View - Story View - visual for parent epic
Make issue status visible on parent issues
Improve speed of completing updates in Portfolio
Ability to move stories easily from sprint to sprint in Portfolio plan itself
Add restrictions / permissions for committing issues within a plan

Parent link JQL should not be case sensitive

For MSSQL:

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1646].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
Switching the theme or changing any other settings in schedule settings can take more than 5 seconds to load when using IE 11 on Windows 10. Sometimes, IE is showing a script issue and ask whether to cancel it. 

h3. Environment
* JIRA version 1000.383.2 Cloud
* Portfolio Live Plan 2.0.9-OD-001-D20160923T012537 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create plan
# View the plan
# Change any of the settings in the Scheduled Settings (i.e Switching scheme)

h3. Expected Results
Loading time should be similar to other browser

h3. Actual Results
Loading time is slow

h3. Workaround
Use other browser except for IE 11. (Tested and seems to be working okay when using other browser)
fields.summary: Slow loading time when changing any of the settings in the Schedule Settings on IE11 (Windows 10)

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1642].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Newly created issues do not have a team assigned to them. Therefore although they may have a sprint associated in JIRA side, the sprint information will not be recognized by Portfolio unless a team is assigned to the issue. Therefore once the issue is created you have to go to portfolio and set the team for the sprint information to show up and then this should be committed back to JIRA. 

h3. Suggested Solution
 Portfolio should automatically set a new issue to a Team
fields.summary: As an user, I want Portfolio to automatically assign new issues to a team

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1640].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Description

JIRA Portfolio doesn't currently have a feature to print a report hence users will have to use the browser feature (pressing Ctrl+p) to workaround it. However, when _Schedule report_ contains a lot of projects, the workaround is no longer working as it only prints/shows a single page.

h3. Suggested Resolution

Provide a feature to print the report.
fields.summary: A feature to print Portfolio report
Use parent link between Story and Task

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}

h3. Summary

h3. Steps to Reproduce

Add releases to gantt

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1632].
  {panel}

Portfolio introduced a custom field to show the parent relations directly on JIRA issues.
When editing this field a search is performed to help the user find the appropriate parent issue.
The search implementation has a bug resulting in an excessive memory consumption, which impacts performance severely and may even result in memory errors which require a restart of the JIRA instance.

To avoid this situation, please remove the Parent Link custom field from all of your issue screens.
fields.summary: Usage of Parent Link custom field search results in excessive memory consumption

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1631].
  {panel}

The 'Cyclic Dependency' error in Portfolio for JIRA points out when dependency links have been set up incorrectly in JIRA.
As a result of detecting this error the tool will then not schedule the work at all (which is probably correct), but there is very little information on the error to go on, which results in a lot of manual searching through JIRA. 
If, for example, you have a cyclic dependency on a couple of stories, the error will appear on those stories AND the parent Epic AND all of the stories in that Epic AND anything else that may be linked to the Initiative above it. This means when you are viewing the Initiative you know there is an error _somewhere_ underneath, but you have to go through every Epic and Story in turn to find the problem, which is very time-consuming.
It _is_ a user error, but it would be very helpful if the error/warning could direct you to the offending issues, either diagrammatically or textually.
fields.summary: Cyclic dependency error should provide more information

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1630].
  {panel}

*Summary*
JIRA performance is generally low, the instance might run out of memory and garbage collection is running constantly and takes very long.

*Steps to reproduce*
At the current stage of investigation we believe this is related to Portfolio's _Parent link_ field search that was added 2.0.6. That is, when you try to search for parents in JIRA's Create or Edit issue dialogs, this may lead to memory problems on larger instances. This problem is aggravated by the fact that every keystroke triggers a new search request.
Another problem is the related search for Portfolio child issues. This is triggered when opening issues above story level in Portfolio.

*Workaround*
To stop this problem from re-occurring, remove the Portfolio parent link field from all screens in your JIRA instance to keep people from triggering the parent search which is the suspected source of trouble.
There is currently no workaround available to prevent the child issue search.

We are working on this issue with highest priority and should be able to provide a fix soon.
fields.summary: Possible performance issues and out-of-memory exceptions on larger instances when searching for Portfolio parents or child issues in JIRA

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1624].
  {panel}

h3. Motivation

As a Product Owner I want to have more control over the Roadmap generated by JIRA Portfolio 2.0 to achieve the most useful and informative results for my stakeholders.
h3. Background

The idea of generating data driven roadmaps via JIRA Portfolio 2.0 is awesome. Unfortunately the scheduler behaves "too smart" from time to time. Especially when it decides to prepone tickets that were prioritized lower for the sake of filling up sprints and to optimize capacity workload across sprints. The workaround of using dependencies is troublesome since you might end up chaining a lot of tickets to prevent JIRA Portfolio 2.0 to prepone some other tickets which is even lower in the backlog.

Also the automatic assignment of Teams to a Story or Epic is more often a burden than of help.

It's ok, that these functionalities are there. But I would love them to be optional and use only the criteria that I need.
fields.summary: Make scheduling criteria and automatic assignment of teams optional
Highlight whole dependency chains (Live Plans)
Better zooming capability (Live Plans)
'Plan of plans' view

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1620].
  {panel}

Relates to JPO-1532

Auto-scheduling of dependencies is done in such a way at the moment that it does not work for plans with more than one team/backlog who have dependencies between those backlogs. It only works reliably for dependencies _within_ the same backlog.

This is because a blocked item will be assigned a virtual rank below the item that is blocking it, and does not take dates into account in any way. This means that for teams with independent backlogs (and with no knowledge of the rank of the other team's issues) dependency scheduling can be very strange indeed (see JPO-1532).

A workaround for this is to disable the auto-scheduling of dependencies, but this removes one the of the most attractive features of Portfolio for JIRA.
A much better way, and more intuitive way, of scheduling dependencies is to do so based on the predicted end date/final sprint of the blocking item.
fields.summary: Auto-scheduling of dependencies based on date, not rank

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1619].
  {panel}

In Portfolio Live Plans in the Shedule report it is very hard to do planning when all everything is the same color.

In the old Portfolio it was in Reports possible to set Coloring on Streams, Stages and Themes. I uses this daily when doing prioritization between multiple project deliveries competing for the same resources.

In Portfolio Live Plans it is only possible to set Coloring to Single or Theme. I would like to be able to set the Coloring on:

1) higher hierarchy levels, e.g. initiative.

2) Versions = Releases

This missing feature is at present blocking us in moving from the old Portfolio to Porfolio 2..0.
fields.summary: Portfolio Live Plans: Reports coloring of more than Single and Theme
Progress visible on schedule view (Live Plans)

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1617].
  {panel}

h2. Problem

Currently there is no daily scheduling within Scrum sprints or hourly schedule within Kanban projects.

Portfolio tries to solve a scheduling problem involving humans in a domain where stories are known to be difficult to estimate.
 When the story estimates are precise and stories are dependent on the results of previous stories in a sequential manner, Portfolio is not able to schedule accurately.

If on a Kanban project, short dependent stories that are meant to be sequential, they can be either scheduled concurrently (if resources are available) or on different days.
 In Scrum projects, dependent stories will either be scheduled concurrently (if resources are available) or on different sprints. There is no sub-sprint granularity.

As an scheduler, I'd like stories with dependencies to be scheduled after the completion of the blocking story but in the same sprint or day if resources permit.
h2. Configuration Examples:

When using Portfolio in Scrum mode:
 * With Dependent Story Constraint switched on, dependant stories can't be in the same sprint, even if they have a short duration.
 * With Dependant Story Constraint switched off, the blocked story won't start before the dependant story but stories may be scheduled concurrently, so the dependant stories may be scheduled by Portfolio before the dependant story is complete and can actually be worked on.

When using Portfolio in Kanban mode:
 * With Dependent Story Constraint switched on, dependant stories are scheduled the next day, disregarding the estimates. 3 dependent stories of 1h are scheduled in 3 different days.
 * With Dependant Story Constraint switched off, dependent stories may be scheduled concurrently and 3 dependent stories of 6h scheduled in the same 8h day if resources allow.

The ON option doesn't allow for stories to be scheduled in a sequential manner with a granularity of hours.
 The OFF option is expected to ignore story completion dependency.
h2. Suggestion:

I'd like an option to enforce more granularity, so the schedule is done on an hourly basis for Kanban and daily basis for Scrum.
 Alternatively: a configurable timespan (week or sprint) to calculate at a higher granularity.
h2. Notes:

The time granularity is a linear factor in the complexity of the scheduling algorithm and increases will cause slowness when calculating the schedule.
h2. Use cases:
 * Sequential stories for operational Kanban teams. Some stories are done manually and others automated and normally short (1h). Estimates are precise.
 * Scrum teams that have well planned dependencies that form a chain of concurrent stories that may or may not fit the sprint.
fields.summary: Improve scheduling granularity

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1616].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition

When user has a lot of exceptions, Portfolio would take up to 5 minutes to open the users page.

 !Screen Shot 2016-09-16 at 1.59.05 PM.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Suggested Solution

Option to delete all exceptions at once, as Portfolio gets degraded.
fields.summary: Option to bulk delete user exceptions on availability
Calendar View of all absences at a team level
Ability to easily add Recurring Absence/Exception

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1612].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition

In Portfolio, you may specify a team associated with the issues in your plan. The team is a Portfolio specific field and doesn't persist into the JIRA Issue when the issue is committed and the issue is created.

Users would like to know the Portfolio team who was associated with an issue, even when reviewing the issue from JIRA and not Portfolio.

h3. Suggested Solution
 
Create a dedicated field/custom field for the team that Portfolio can set during issue creation.
fields.summary: Create field in JIRA to hold Portfolio Team value

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1611].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

When a JIRA Portfolio Plan is connected to an existing project where, in order to create an issue, the following fields are *Required* under that Project's Field Configuration:

* *Description* field
* Another field, such as a test custom field

When committing a change, such as a new Epic/Story/etc., the Set Required Fields Screen will be brought up so that the user may populate that other required field. In the process, the *Description* field is also brought up but it does not retain the description that may have been added in Portfolio.



The issue cannot be created without the user repopulating the Description again since it is a required field.

h3. Environment
* JIRA 7.1.6
* Portfolio 2.0.6

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Create a new project
# Create a new custom field (e.g. "Test", which is a Single Line Text Field)
# Configure the project's field configuration so that *Description* and *Test* are +Required+
# Create a new plan and associate it with this project
# Create a new Epic and give it a description in Portfolio
# Commit the change

At this point, you will find that the issue isn't automatically created since the user needs to populate *Test*. *Description* will be blank. Cannot proceed with creating the issue until *Description* is populated again.

h3. Expected Results

Description should be retained from Portfolio into the Set Required Fields screen during the commit. Completing the commit should create the issue with the Description.

h3. Actual Results
Description is not retained in the Set Required Fields screen during the commit.
 
h3.Workaround
Either:

1. Repopulate the description at the Set Required Fields screen
or
2. Set Description to be Optional in the project's field configuration, which will prevent it from coming up during the Set Required Fields screen. The description is retained at the time of issue creation this way.
fields.summary: Requiring Description and another field causes description to be lost when committing changes

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1610].
  {panel}

h3. Existing Behavior
Currently the project key is shown to the left of the swimlane. If the project key is more than three characters only the first two characters will shown. 
* Example: The project key "LONGNAME" will appear as "LO..." 

 !Screen Shot 2016-09-12 at 4.42.59 PM.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Suggested Behavior
It should be easier to tell which project the swimlane is referring to. This could be being able to change the size of the left bar, showing more characters, or perhaps by being able to hover over the abbreviated key to view the full key and project name.
fields.summary: Make it easier to tell which project a timeline swimlane project key is referring to
Add "empty" to filter selections
Have Team and Theme inherit the parent issue's values
Mapping of Portfolio teams into Jira

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1606].
  {panel}

Problem Definition

When downloading JIRA Portfolio through the [Atlassian Marketplace|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.radiantminds.roadmaps-jira/server/overview], it is stated that JIRA Server 6.3 - 7.2.1 are supported. However, Live Plans requires JIRA Software 7.0.5+, which is currently not specified on the page. When trying to create a plan, the user will be met with the following error:

 !Screen Shot 2016-09-12 at 2.17.52 PM.png|thumbnail! 

Currently, it is only possible to create plans for JIRA Portfolio 2+ on instances that are running JIRA Software 7.0.5+. It is possible to use JIRA Portfolio 1.12.7 with older versions of JIRA Software, but Live Plans will not be available.

Suggested Solution

Specify on the Marketplace that JIRA Portfolio 2+ requires at least JIRA Software 7.0.5 to be installed on the instance.
fields.summary: Specify JIRA Software requirements on the Marketplace
Bring back the Originally Planned field or provide a vehicle for saving baseline estimates to compare with current estimates
Ability to show percentages based on issue count in Reports
Bulk Update for Releases, Teams, and Themes Columns in Scope
Portfolio Timeline Roadmap by Releases across Projects Plus Print/Share
Scope Release Progress Shows # of # Issues Bar

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1600].
{panel}

h3. Problem Description
When Subtask has dependency on other Subtask of the same parent, the parent (Story) will display one of the below error messages:
 - "Cyclic dependency detected"
- "This issue can't be scheduled due to dependencies between its sub-tasks"

h3. Suggested Resolution
Allow Subtask to have dependency to other Subtask.
fields.summary: Allow Subtask to have dependency to other Subtask

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1593].
  {panel}

The detailed error message includes:

Caused by java.lang.IllegalStateException: value is absent

  at com.google.common.base.Optional$Absent.get:263
  at com.atlassian.rm.jpo.core.scheduling.trafo.backlog.ProcessingItemsTransformer.createProcessingItems:135
  at com.atlassian.rm.jpo.core.scheduling.trafo.backlog.ProcessingItemsTransformer.transform:66
  at com.atlassian.rm.jpo.core.scheduling.trafo.backlog.DefaultBacklogTransformer.transform:64
  at com.atlassian.rm.jpo.core.scheduling.trafo.plan.DefaultSchedulingProblemTransformer.transform:88
  at com.atlassian.rm.jpo.core.scheduling.trafo.plan.DefaultSchedulingProblemTransformer.transformPlan:57
  at com.atlassian.rm.jpo.core.scheduling.calc.NonPersistingSchedulingSolutionService.getSchedulingSolution:46
  at com.atlassian.rm.jpo.core.scheduling.jobs.CalculationJob.run:76
  at com.atlassian.rm.jpo.core.scheduling.jobs.CalculationJob.run:49
  at com.atlassian.jpo.env.threading.JiraLongRunningExecutorRegistry$1$1.run:72
  at com.atlassian.jpo.jira.api.threading.JiraSafeThreadService$1.run:48
  at java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call:-1
  at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run:-1
  at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker:-1
  at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run:-1
  at java.lang.Thread.run:-1

*Workaround*
At this point the only known way to get the calculation running again is by disabling the default estimate feature in the scheduling configuration.
fields.summary: Unexpected scheduling error when using default estimates

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1592].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Currently, on the scope view, users are able to filter by teams. Sometimes users would like to be able to track the progress by team members.

h3. Suggested Solution
Have the ability to filter scope view by team member(s).
 
h3. Workaround
Make a team consisting of only that user and filtering the scope view by that team.
fields.summary: Able to filter scope view by team member(s)
